newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs fall sharply towards close on BOJ comments.
newsitem.headline: JGBs fall sharply towards close on BOJ comments.

text.p: The key June Japanese government bond futures contract fell sharply on Tuesday due to comments by a senior Bank of Japan official which seemed to imply that the recent surge in JGBs had been overdone, traders said.
Masayuki Matsushima, director of the BOJ's research and statistics department, told reporters that the market does not always move in line with economic fundamentals.
"The market sometimes overshoots," he said.
The June ended at 125.95, down sharply from the previous day's close of 126.62. Turnover was 48,277 contracts.

Matsushima said there is a theory that long-term interest rates move on expectations regarding inflation, and that theory may be confirmed when the movements of the rates are observed over the long term.
"We may need more time to assess the basic trend of long-term interest rates," he said.
The comments, which reached the market late in the afternoon, suggested that the BOJ wanted to check a further fall in long-term rates and led to selling, traders said.
The impact on the market is likely to persist, at least in the near-term, a trust bank trader said.
JGBs had been falling late in the afternoon, even before the BOJ official's comments came out.
Selling of medium-term cash JGBs were behind the initial fall, a brokerage house trader said. The BOJ official's comments increased the downward momentum, he said.
The benchmark 182nd JGB yield stood at 2.285 percent as of 0658 GMT, up from the previous day's close of 2.205 percent.
Earlier in the day, JGBs were pulled down by Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka's comments which said that a government scheme for improving land liquidity will be announced at the end of March.
Mitsuzuka said he was told by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on Tuesday to draw up the plan.
"If we make effective use of land, it is true that this will have an impact on solving problem loans quickly for financial firms," Mitsuzuka said.
Traders said the impact from Mitsuzuka's announcement was limited, however, as no specific details were yet available.
"Until the details are released it will be hard to decide how much to sell based on this news alone," a trader for a trust bank's securities unit said.
One key for the market in the near term will be whether investors decide to buy cash JGBs on dips, the trust bank trader said.
"Market players were saying that if JGBs fell to below 126.00, investors would probably decide to buy cash bonds," he said.
The market will be focusing on whether such buying actually emerges or not, he said.
-- Masayuki Kitano, Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-3-5473-3748
